timeline.event: Levelling Up and Regeneration Act receives Royal Assent
timeline.detail: Gives Secretary of State powers to create unitary authorities without local consent
English Devolution White Paper signals push for reorganisation
Framework for Mayoral Strategic Authorities and mandatory unitarisation
Government invites proposals for new unitary structures in Lancashire
Deadline for submissions on proposed unitary boundaries
Secretary of State announces chosen boundary model
Voters elect councillors for new unitary authorities
New unitary authorities go live, all 15 current councils abolished

proposed_models.name: Two Unitaries
proposed_models.description: Government-preferred model. North and South Lancashire, each with 500,000+ population.

authorities.name: North Lancashire
authorities.notes: East Lancashire mill towns + rural Ribble Valley + coastal Wyre + historic Lancaster

authorities.name: South Lancashire
authorities.notes: Preston city region + commuter belt + rural West Lancashire

proposed_models.notes: Blackpool and Blackburn with Darwen already unitary — would remain separate or merge. LCC abolished.

proposed_models.name: Three Unitaries
proposed_models.description: Compromise model. East Lancashire, Central Lancashire, and West/Coast.

authorities.name: East Lancashire
authorities.notes: Strong economic ties, shared deprivation challenges, existing East Lancs partnerships

authorities.name: Central Lancashire
authorities.notes: Existing City Deal partnership, strong commuter flows, Preston as admin capital

authorities.name: West & Coastal Lancashire
authorities.notes: Diverse geography — Lancaster university city, Wyre/Fylde coast, rural West Lancs

proposed_models.notes: Most commonly discussed model among district leaders. Blackpool and Blackburn with Darwen remain separate.

proposed_models.name: Five Unitaries
proposed_models.description: District-preferred model. Smallest units, closest to existing partnerships.

authorities.name: East Lancashire
authorities.notes: Strongest political support. Existing joint services and shared challenges

authorities.name: Lancaster & Wyre
authorities.notes: Northern coastal authorities with M6 corridor connection

authorities.name: Fylde & West Lancashire
authorities.notes: Smallest proposed unitary — may not meet government population threshold

authorities.name: Blackpool & Fylde Coast
authorities.notes: Alternative grouping: coastal strip with shared tourism economy

proposed_models.notes: Government unlikely to accept 5+ unitaries (Devon/Somerset precedent: 2 unitaries from 10 councils). Overlapping groupings show tension in this model.

key_issues.title: LCC Debt Transfer
key_issues.description: Lancashire CC holds significant borrowing including the VeLTIP bond portfolio (£519M invested, ~£169M current value). How this debt is distributed to successor authorities is the single biggest financial risk.

key_issues.title: Reserves Distribution
key_issues.description: Combined reserves across all 15 councils must be fairly divided. Some councils have strong reserves (Fylde, Chorley) while others are depleted. Earmarked reserves tied to specific obligations complicate distribution.

key_issues.title: Dedicated Schools Grant Deficit
key_issues.description: LCC carries a DSG deficit projected to reach £419.9M by 2028/29. This statutory obligation for SEND provision will transfer to successor authorities.

key_issues.title: Staff TUPE Transfer
key_issues.description: Approximately 30,000+ staff across all 15 councils will need TUPE transfer to successor authorities. Different pay scales, pension schemes, and terms must be harmonised — typically the most expensive part of reorganisation.

key_issues.title: IT System Consolidation
key_issues.description: 15 councils run different IT systems for revenues, planning, housing, and corporate services. LCC's Oracle Fusion implementation has been plagued with problems. System consolidation typically costs £20-50M per new authority.
key_issues.figure_label: Estimated IT cost per new authority

key_issues.title: Total Transition Cost
key_issues.description: Based on Buckinghamshire, Dorset, and Somerset precedents, total reorganisation costs are typically £15-25M per new unitary authority over the transition period.
key_issues.figure_label: Estimated total transition cost (depending on model)

precedents.notes: Often cited as success story. Single unitary from 4 districts + county.
Two unitaries — Dorset Council (rural) + BCP (Bournemouth, Christchurch, Poole).

Largest geographic area. 7 districts + county → single unitary. City of York already unitary.
